1.name: concurrent computing
1.description: form of computing in which several computations are executing during overlapping time periods

2.name: reactive programming
2.description: programming paradigm focused on data flow and change propragation

6.name: imperative programming
6.description: type of programming paradigm in computer science

7.name: visual programming language
7.description: computer programming language to create programs by manipulating program elements graphically

10.name: structured programming
10.description: programming paradigm aimed at improving clarity, quality, and development time by using control structures

14.name: parallel computing
14.description: programming paradigm in which many calculations or the execution of processes are carried out simultaneously

16.name: generic programming
16.description: way of designing and writing programs where algorithms are written in terms of parametric types enabling easy reuse

17.name: reflective programming
17.description: ability of a process to examine and modify itself

18.name: purely functional programming
18.description: programming paradigm that treats all computation as the evaluation of mathematical functions

19.name: concurrent object-oriented programming
19.description: programming paradigm that combines object-oriented programming (OOP) together with concurrency

20.name: declarative programming
20.description: programming paradigm that expresses the logic of a computation without describing its control flow

22.name: agent-oriented programming
22.description: programming paradigm centred on the concept of software agents

23.name: object-oriented programming
23.description: programming paradigm based on the concept of objects

24.name: logic programming
24.description: programming paradigm based on formal logic

25.name: constraint logic programming
25.description: Programming paradigm which combines logic programming and constraint satisfaction

26.name: constraint programming
26.description: programming paradigm wherein relations between variables are stated in the form of constraints

27.name: functional reactive programming
27.description: programming paradigm for reactive programming using key features of functional programming

29.name: stack-oriented programming
29.description: programming paradigm that relies on a stack machine model

31.name: array programming
31.description: programming paradigm that generalize operations on scalars to apply transparently to higher-dimensional arrays

32.name: dataflow programming
32.description: programming paradigm that models program as a directed graph of data flow between operations

34.name: synchronous programming
34.description: programming paradigm supported by synchronous programming languages
